headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications

headline: 2010 Financial Restatements: A Ten Year Comparison
summary: After three years of decline, financial restatements experienced an uptick in quantity in 2010, largely due to non-accelerated filers, but the severity of these restatements remained low.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Heading for the Exits
summary: See a list of more than 80 bankers that have left UBS since 2006, and where they've gone.

headline: Postnatal Depression Screening Test
summary: Take the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale, which was developed to screen postpartum women for depression.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of May 17, 2011

headline: Treasury to Sell $33 Billion
summary: The offerings include $28 billion in four-week bills.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for May 17, 2011

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for May 17, 2011

headline: Geithner Wants Debt Ceiling Vote by July
summary: Treasury Secretary Geithner said he wanted a vote to raise the debt ceiling "done and clean" by July, weeks before the government could potentially default on its debts on Aug. 2.

headline: Vodafone Hints at Small Indian IPO
summary: Vodafone Group executives hinted that the mobile giant could sell some of its Indian business in an initial public offering to ensure it complies with local foreign direct-investment rules.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: Pakistan, Victim of Terrorism?
summary: To sustain the war on terror in this country, the rest of the world should bolster Islamabad's storyline.

headline: U.K. Inflation at 4.5%
summary: U.K. inflation accelerated to 4.5% in the year to April, official statistics showed, boosted by a jump in travel costs as Britons headed abroad during the Easter holidays.

headline: U.S. Stocks Fall
summary: The Dow industrials ended down 68.79 after falling much more steeply early in the trading day following Hewlett Packard's negative outlook and downbeat economic data.

headline: Markets Fall as Manufacturing Report Fuels Worries
summary: Markets turned lower as investors spooked by weak U.S. economic data ditched assets that have value tied to a robust recovery.

headline: Geithner: IMF Needs Plan for Leadership
summary: U.S. Treasury Secretary Geithner said it was important that the IMF establish a leadership plan given that its boss was currently "not in the position" to run the institution.

headline: Colombia to Start Ecopetrol Stake Sale in 2011
summary: Colombia's finance minister said the sale of a portion of state-controlled oil company Ecopetrol to help pay for recovery from torrential rains and floods remains on track to start before year-end.

headline: Canada Scrambles to Contain Fires
summary: Firefighters in Alberta, Canada, scrambled Tuesday to contain dozens of forest fires, which have already destroyed hundreds of homes, forced the evacuation of thousands, and are now shutting down an increasing amount of the province's oil output.

headline: Massey Official Faces New Charge
summary: U.S. prosecutors announced a third charge against the chief of security Massey's Upper Big Branch mine where an explosion killed 29 miners last year.

headline: The Gamble House, Before and After
summary: For the past year, two sides have been warring over the grand old home of Ivory soap's inventor, James Norris Gamble, in Cincinnati.

headline: Schwab Investors Vote to Elect Directors Every Year
summary: Charles Schwab's shareholders approved an investor proposal that requires all members of the discount brokerage's board to stand for election on an annual basis, rather than staggered three-year terms.

headline: Sarkozy Says Party Won't Exploit Strauss-Kahn Woes
summary: France's President Nicolas Sarkozy urged members of his conservative ruling party not to appear to be taking advantage of the legal woes of IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn.

headline: Pandit's Rescue Story
summary: None

headline: Chesapeake Fined $1.09 Million in Pennsylvania
summary: The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection has fined Chesapeake Energy Corp. nearly $1.09 million for contaminating the drinking water of 16 families with natural gas, and, separately, for an explosion at a condensate storage tank.

headline: Bay State On Road to Single-Payer
summary: Your editorial's criticism of Mitt Romney's 2006 Massachusetts health law is correct in that taxes, costs and political interference in medical decisions have all gone up while access to medical care has deteriorated ("Obama's Running Mate," May 12).

headline: Great Homes
summary: See other homes owned by prominent American families.

headline: HSBC to Hire in Singapore, China
summary: HSBC Holdings said that it plans to hire more than 2,000 staff in Singapore and mainland China over the next five years, as the U.K. banking giant continues its expansion in Asia, its fastest-growing region.

headline: Wal-Mart U.S. Sales Decline Further
summary: Wal-Mart's first-quarter profit rose 3% as international-sales strength continued to drive results, while U.S. operations struggled.

headline: Citadel Eases Withdrawal Rules on Its Two Biggest Funds
summary: Investors in Citadel's Kensington and Wellington funds will get easier redemption terms, hedge-fund manager Ken Griffin said in an investor letter.

headline: Yen Slips, But Bulls Hold Their Ground
summary: Investors who keep looking for the yen to fall could continue to be disappointed.

headline: Crude Ends Near 3-Month Lows
summary: Crude-oil futures pared losses late in the day but still ended down, near three-month lows, as the dollar reversed course. The expiration of options on some crude contracts contributed to trading volatility.

headline: Gold Falls as Funds Exit
summary: Gold futures ended at a one-month low after several hedge funds disclosed they dumped their holdings of the precious metal in the first quarter.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 17
summary: In today's pictures, surfers compete in Rio de Janeiro, Buddhist monks celebrate Buddha in Thailand, a woman gets wrapped up at a beauty expo in Japan and more.

headline: Natural Gas Retreats
summary: Natural-gas futures settled 3.2% lower after surprisingly weak data on U.S. manufacturers, who account for one-third of U.S. natural-gas demand.

headline: The Mounting Cost of BP's Russian Adventure
summary: For BP and Rosneft, deadlines aren't necessarily dead ends. A tie-up with Rosneft may have seemed a strategic breakthrough for BP in January. But this never-ending story is trying shareholder's patience.

headline: Portugual's Banks Start Using Government Guarantees
summary: Banco Espírito Santo will float bonds backed in country's bailout, while other lenders could follow.

headline: Capital One Reshuffles Banking Executives
summary: Capital One Financial promoted two banking executives and eliminated a layer of management, changes reflecting its transformation in the past five years from a credit card lender to a retail bank.

headline: European Stocks Fall Broadly
summary: Stocks in Europe ended a choppy session firmly in the red  as uncertainty over Greece and downbeat data from both sides of the Atlantic undermined sentiment.

headline: At J.P. Morgan Meeting: Protests Outside, Peace Inside
summary: J.P. Morgan Chief Executive James Dimon faced a relatively calm annual meeting with shareholders. Outside the meeting, however, it was a different story as protestors decried mortgage practices

headline: U.S. Continues Push to Retain Smallpox Cache
summary: The U.S. government has asked global health officials to agree to retain the last known stockpiles of smallpox for now and conduct a review of research progress in another five years.

headline: Vodafone Isn't So Upwardly Mobile
summary: The latest earnings show that Vodafone has hit its stride. But there are good reasons to be cautious about the outlook for the shares of the U.K. telecommunications operator.

headline: Pfizer's Application for Cancer Drug Accepted by FDA
summary: Pfizer's new application to sell experimental cancer drug crizotinib was given priority status by the FDA.

headline: South Korea Restarts Woori Stake Sale
summary: South Korea said it is restarting the sale of its 57% stake in Woori Finance, currently valued at $5.63 billion.

headline: African Barrick Says 7 Killed in Mine Invasion
summary: African Barrick Gold said seven people were killed and twelve injured after hundreds of people invaded one if its mines in Northern Tanzania in an attempt to steal gold.

headline: Apache Pursuing Shale-Oil Drilling in Egypt
summary: Apache Corp. plans to explore deeply buried rock formations, including shales, in Egypt's Western Desert for oil and natural gas beginning later this year.

headline: Slow Turnover Rate for CEOs
summary: The recession prompted CEOs and companies to stay the course, despite poorer performance

headline: State Bank of India Profit Slumps 99%
summary: State Bank of India said fourth-quarter net profit sank 99% because of a surge in provisions against bad loans and higher tax expenses.

headline: EU Reaches Deal to Limit Short-Selling
summary: European Union finance ministers reached an agreement on rules limiting the short-selling of shares and sovereign debt, overcoming concern from the U.K. that the legislation will give the EU's new securities regulator too much power.

headline: Carrefour Defends Dia Spin-Off Plan
summary: Carrefour sought to rally support for its heavily-criticized plan to spin off the discount chain Dia, as it tries to reassure critics of its turnaround strategy amid difficult trading conditions.

headline: BP to Sell U.K. Oil Fields to Perenco for $610 Million
summary: BP said Tuesday it has agreed to sell its interests in Wytch Farm, one of the U.K.'s few onshore oil fields, and three other fields to privately held Perenco U.K. for up to $610 million in cash.

headline: Citi Could See Big Gains From China Bank IPO
summary: China Guangfa Bank, the provincial bank 20% owned by Citigroup, is planning to raise up to $5 billion in a dual Hong Kong-Shanghai listing.

headline: France Calls for Restraint in Airing Strauss-Kahn Images
summary: France's broadcasting watchdog called on TV channels to use restraint in showing footage of International Monetary Fund managing director Dominique Strauss-Kahn in handcuffs.

headline: Parmalat Board Rejects Lactalis Bid
summary: Parmalat's board said it considered as inadequate the bid price of $3.70 a share offered by Groupe Lactalis for the rest of the Italian dairy group that it does not own.

headline: Q&A With Sony CEO on Hacker Attack
summary: Sony CEO Howard Stringer spoke to the WSJ about how he sees online attacks shaping up in the future and his assessment of how Sony handled the matter.

headline: Donald Ducks 2012 Bid
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  Trump watchers became convinced that The Donald would never run for president because he would be compelled to file a financial disclosure statement.

headline: Shell CEO Stresses Interest in Arctic
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has made "no secret" of its interest in developing the hydrocarbon resources in the Russian Arctic, but its preference remains for investment on a project-by-project basis rather than buying stakes in local companies, its CEO said.

headline: Hall of Fame Slugger Killebrew Dies
summary: Harmon Killebrew, the Minnesota Twin known for his tape-measure home runs, has died at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 74.

headline: Home Depot's Net Rises
summary: Home Depot's first-quarter profit rose 12% as the retailer saw a surprise drop in sales, though costs declined. The company also raised its full-year forecast.

headline: Hyundai to Double Alabama Engine Plant Capacity
summary: Hyundai said it will invest $173 million to double production capacity at its Alabama engine plant so that most engines for its popular Elantra compact car can be produced locally rather than shipped from South Korea.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: A smooth auction of 40-year Japanese government bonds proved insufficient to buoy the market overall, with yields rising as investors turned from bonds to equities.

headline: Beijing Jingdong Sets Sights on $2 Billion U.S. IPO
summary: The owner of China's 360buy.com aims to raise at least $2 billion in an initial public offering in the U.S. in 2013 or later, its chief executive officer said, in a sign of booming growth and intensifying competition in China's online retail market.

headline: Outdoor Living
summary: While private outdoor space in Hong Kong is a rarity, this flat in Mid-Levels boasts a larger area outdoors than in: The newly renovated 1,400-square-foot apartment—all white and light tones—comes with a 3,100-square-foot rooftop with a harbor view.

headline: Sabic to Tap China's Demand for Plastics
summary: Saudi Basic Industries plans to build a $1 billion polycarbonate plant in northern China with joint-venture partner Sinopec.

headline: 'Not Responsible' to Ditch German Nuclear Power
summary: The German environment minister said that a scientific review of the country's 17 nuclear reactors found that the power plants meet high safety requirements, with the report being "no argument for an immediate" exit from atomic electricity production.

headline: Converted English Barn
summary: This six-bedroom property, an hour and a half from London in Oxfordshire, retains some of the oak features of the original 200-year-old building.

headline: Euro-Zone Crisis 'Biggest Risk' to Czech Outlook
summary: A growing Czech economy means monetary policy will be tightened this year, but the euro zone's fiscal crisis and its lack of appropriate rules cast a shadow over the country's economic outlook, the newest member of the Czech central bank board said.

headline: Burst of Asset-Backed, Commercial Mortgage Bonds Offered
summary: More than $5.5 billion of asset-backed securities came to market Monday.

headline: Tepco Shares Plummet
summary: Tokyo Electric Power shares fell 9.5% in the stock's worst single-day share sell-off in more than a month as concern mounted over the company's debts.

headline: Gamesa Gets $2 Billion Order for India Wind Project
summary: Gamesa Wind Turbines, the Indian unit of Spain's Gamesa Corporacion Tecnologica, said it received an order valued at $2 billion from the local unit of Caparo Energy to build 2,000 megawatt of wind power projects in India.

headline: Ford to Expand Indian Engine Plant
summary: Ford Motor said it will invest $72 million in its Indian operations until the middle of next year to raise the capacity of its engine and transmission plant by more than 30%.

headline: China Foreign Direct Investment Rises 15%
summary: Actual foreign direct investment in China rose 15.2% in April from a year earlier, to $8.46 billion, the Ministry of Commerce said.

headline: Infosys China Plans to Triple Staff
summary: Infosys Technologies China plans to triple its staff in China to 10,000 over the next three years as part of its expansion aimed at securing a larger share in China's outsourcing technology services sector.

headline: Mahanagar Telephone to Restructure Debt
summary: Mahanagar Telephone Nigam plans to restructure about $664 million of short-term loans into long-term debt in a bid to extend the repayment schedule of the money it raised to pay for third-generation communication bandwidth.

headline: Choppy Day Leaves Asia Markets Mixed
summary: Chinese and Australian markets crept higher as investors piled into beaten-down commodity stocks, and Tokyo overcame utility undertow to finish up for the day—but Mumbai was slammed by State Bank of India's disappointing results.

headline: EU Juncker: Greece Crisis Difficult, More Measures Needed
summary: Greece's economic crisis is more difficult to solve than others' in the 17-member euro zone, requiring its government to take additional measures, eurogroup President Jean-Claude Juncker says, adding that the country's debt level is "unsustainable."

headline: BAE to Pay $79 Million in U.S. Civil Case
summary: BAE Systems said it would pay up to $79 million to the U.S. State Department to settle a civil case brought against it due to violations of U.S. defense export-control regulations.

headline: Nissan Says Quake-Damaged Plant Restored
summary: Nissan Chief Executive Carlos Ghosn said the company repaired production lines at its most earthquake-damaged plant ahead of schedule, while rival Honda said its earnings were likely to suffer from supply disruptions and the strong yen.

headline: MGM China Plans Hong Kong IPO
summary: MGM China is seeking to raise as much as $1.5 billion in an initial public offering in Hong Kong.

headline: Australia Central Bank: Rates Likely to Rise, in Time
summary: Saying inflation pressures are building, Australia's central bank again signaled a growing likelihood that it will raise interest rates soon, but said it will stay its hand for now as it monitors the outlook for growth and inflation.

headline: German Economic Confidence Falls
summary: German economic sentiment deteriorated again in May in light of the euro-zone debt crisis.

headline: Aviva's Life-Insurance Sales Fall
summary: U.K. insurer Aviva posted a 14% drop in first-quarter life insurance sales, due in part to smaller contributions from Europe and the U.S., but the company said its business is expected to "thrive" this year.

headline: Publicis Buys U.S. Digital Ad Agency
summary: French advertising company Publicis Groupe said it agreed to buy U.S. digital ad agency Rosetta Marketing Group for $575 million in cash, in the group's latest deal to boost its presence in digital advertising and strengthen its position in the world's biggest ad market.

headline: Macau's SJM Posts 85% Profit Increase
summary: Casino operator SJM Holdings said net profit rose to $181.3 million in the latest quarter, on rising gambling revenue in Macau.

headline: Tencent Buys eLong Stake
summary: China's Tencent Holdings bought a minority stake in online travel agent eLong for $84.4 million, in a co-investment with travel site Expedia.

headline: EU's Van Rompuy: Work Together to Correct Imbalances
summary: Countries must work to correct economic imbalances and set exchange rates more in line with economic fundamentals, European Council President Herman Van Rompuy said.

headline: For China, Logistics Improvements Would Deliver Big
summary: Massive government investment in road, rail and air infrastructure means that China's transport network is approaching developed-world standards. But the cost of moving goods from A to B remains high.

headline: Honda Expects Earnings to Take Hit From Quake
summary: Japan's third largest auto maker said the impact of the March 11 earthquake and the yen's strength are likely to weigh on earnings for the fiscal year as production volumes remain at 50% of capacity through June.

headline: Celebrating Buddha's Birthday
summary: India is one of several countries that celebrates Buddha Purnima, the Buddha's birth anniversary, on Tuesday. Some snapshots.

headline: Tata Chemicals Unit Plans Global Bond Sale
summary: General Chemicals Industrial Products, the U.S. unit of Tata Chemicals, plans to raise at least $250 million through a global bond sale.

headline: Euro Zone Endorses Draghi as ECB Chief
summary: Euro-area finance ministers backed Italian central bank chair Mario Draghi as the next head of the European Central Bank, the first formal approval necessary before the official can take the post.

headline: KSK Energy's Founders to Buy up to 20% More Stake
summary: KSK Energy Ventures' three founders offer to buy an additional stake of up to 20% in the company during an open offer between July 9 and July 28.

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Tuesday, May 17, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: China Open to 'Long-Term' FX Talks
summary: China's government is open to long-term discussions of changes in the international foreign exchange system, starting with talks at the G-20 this fall, Chinese Trade Minister Chen Deming said.

headline: Marlins Reliever Beats Mets With 11th-Inning RBI
summary: It's another gut-punch loss for New York, which squandered a rare superb start by Mike Pelfrey.

headline: Developing Iraq's Banking Sector
summary: Atira Abdel Kader, manager of Lebanon-based Byblos Bank's branch in Baghdad, on what it's like to be the female boss of the first foreign bank in Iraq.

headline: Air France Flight Data Salvaged
summary: Investigators successfully downloaded all of the information captured by the flight-data recorder aboard an Air France jet that crashed two years ago, killing 228 people.

headline: New York AG Probes Banks Over Mortgage Securities
summary: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman will hold meetings with several banks, including Bank of America, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, as he opens a probe into the packaging of mortgage loans into securities.

headline: Profit Soars as Dell Refocuses
summary: Dell's profit nearly tripled as the computer maker benefited from strong corporate demand and rising sales of its higher-margin products.

headline: H-P Chief Warns of 'Tough Quarter'
summary: H-P's chief, Leo Apotheker, said the technology company was in for "another tough quarter" and that "we must watch every penny," according to an email to top executives.

headline: Gadhafi and the Vanished Imam
summary: The 1978 murder of a luminary of the Shiite religious class, Imam Musa al-Sadr, foreshadowed the Libyan dictator's later crimes against humanity.

headline: A Bossa Bigwig, Back From Brazil
summary: This week Brazilian singer-songwriter Marcos Valle is back for a rare New York appearance at Birdland with the legendary Brazilian vocalist Wanda Sá.

headline: Pharmaceuticals' Bitter Pricing Pill
summary: Drugs companies are feeling the pain. The industry swallowed government-led cuts of around 3.5% to prescription drug prices in Europe last year. Pharmaceutical groups expect to have to cut prices by a further 4%-5% in 2011, but even that could prove too optimistic.

headline: France Grapples With Strauss-Kahn's Plight
summary: A New York judge's order that International Monetary Fund Managing Director Dominique Strauss-Kahn remain in custody without bail sent a another shock wave through France, among a public already transfixed by images of him handcuffed over the weekend.

headline: Russia to Invest in U.S. Memory-Chip Firm
summary: A Silicon Valley chip start-up is teaming up with a Russian government investment fund on a $300 million manufacturing venture, a boost for a novel memory technology.

headline: Mets Take a Big Hit With Wright's Stress Fracture
summary: An MRI exam reveals a stress fracture in the third baseman's lower back. He's expected to miss 10 days to two weeks.

headline: New Steps for Book Lovers
summary: If you write a column that tries not to shy from the freakish and bizarre, what could be freakier or more bizarre than the opening of a new bookstore?

headline: Ruchir Sharma: Greater Expectations in India
summary: The powerful national parties do badly in local elections. Good.

headline: State Names New Education Chief
summary: John B. King Jr. was elected to the commissioner post, as well as to the position of president of the University of the State of New York, by the New York State Board of Regents.

headline: What's Wrong With the Yankees?
summary: Lately, Most Things—and a Devastating Loss to the Rays After Blowing a Big Lead Punctuates New York's Problems

headline: Will Nasdaq Exchange New York for London?
summary: Rejected before, Nasdaq OMX CEO Robert Greifeld has shown he rebounds quickly. Who will Mr. Greifeld target as his rebound partner this time?

headline: Robo-Copters Eye Enemies
summary: Remote-controlled helicopters that can spy on targets and mark them for attack are expanding the U.S. military's offensive capabilities without exposing Americans to greater casualties.

headline: N.J. Rakes In More Money
summary: A new legislative projection says New Jersey will rake in $914 million more than expected in taxes through June 2012, which will likely set off a fierce partisan fight over how to spend the money.

headline: Draghi's Ascent
summary: Europe's crisis and the next ECB President.

headline: Vatican Seeks Rule on Abuse Claims
summary: The Vatican called on bishops' conferences worldwide to set guidelines for how local dioceses and religious orders handle cases of sexual abuse by clergy.

headline: Uganda Restrains Opposition Leader
summary: Ugandan security forces prevented the country's main opposition leader from leaving his house, in a fresh attempt to halt protests that have threatened to derail the 25-year rule of President Yoweri Museveni.

headline: BATS Names Listings Chief
summary: BATS Global Markets said that Brian King will head its planned push into the business of listing companies' shares, targeted for a fourth-quarter launch this year.

headline: Red Sox Sweep Stumbling Yanks
summary: Now that Jorge Posada and the Yankees are one big family again, there's nothing to distract from the fact that the Yankees just got blown out—in their house—by the rival Red Sox.

headline: Israel Will Never Have Peace
summary: This weekend's border-crossing demonstrators believe, like Hamas, that the Jewish State has no right to any territory from the river to the sea.

headline: A River Roars Through It
summary: The debate over the future of the Mississippi is a talk worth having.

headline: Cuomo Seeks New Pension Tier
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is proposing a new pension plan that would offer less-generous retirement packages to future state and local workers but would largely preserve the state's traditional system of guaranteed benefits.

headline: Netflix to Stream Miramax Movies
summary: Netflix reached a deal to stream hundreds of movies from the Miramax collection.

headline: Bernanke Backs R&D Spending
summary: Fed Chairman Bernanke made the case for public research funding, saying government spending on research and development can help boost economic growth.

headline: Gold One Agrees to Takeover Offer
summary: Gold One International said it has accepted a takeover offer from a Chinese consortium that values the Africa-focused gold producer at $634 million.

headline: Bank Lending Goes Long on High Quality
summary: Banks are lending more to high-quality U.S. companies, and for longer periods, enabling companies to set aside cheap rainy-day funds and build war chests for acquisitions.

headline: Maybe Not a Heidegger, but It Doesn't Make Him Right
summary: Bret Stephens's designation of Martin Heidegger as "the most significant philosopher of the 20th century" is something of an insult to philosophy and philosophers ("From Chomsky to Bin Laden," Global View, May 10). There have been many better, clearer minded, and more moral philosophers than Heidegger.

headline: Trade Pacts Tied to Worker Aid
summary: The White House won't submit trade deals for congressional approval until Republicans renew aid to workers displaced by foreign competition.

headline: Maya Rudolph Is Ready
summary: Maya Rudolph talks about "Bridesmaids," improv comedy, and her time in New York.

headline: A Wreck of Art That Was No Accident
summary: Brooklyn Industries founder Vahap Avsar has returned to his first career with a new exhibit on the Bowery that features a burned-out NYPD police cruiser.

headline: Europe Ministers Wrestle Over Aid
summary: European finance ministers heaped pressure on Greece to make fresh budget reforms and raise cash by selling state assets, even as they debated giving the country billions more in emergency loans.

headline: Galleon Defense Worked—to a Point
summary: Two jury consultants hired by Raj Rajaratnam to help choose the panel that would decide his fate got everything they wanted, except the result.

headline: The Aggrandizing Madoff Trustee
summary: Regarding your editorial "Madoff and the Mets" (May 11): The Trustee's quest for Madoff assets has certainly led to abuses of power against not only the Wilpons, but many other Madoff victims.

headline: Trump Won't Seek White House
summary: Donald Trump said he won't run for president and will continue to host "The Celebrity Apprentice."

headline: Chinese IPOs No Longer Sizzling
summary: U.S. investors have swarmed to Chinese initial public offerings since last fall. But that love affair may be fading.

headline: Japan: Reactor Woes Won't Delay Cleanup
summary: Japan reiterated a pledge to bring the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant under control within nine months.

headline: Padma Lakshmi: Inspiring America's Next Top Cocktails?
summary: Pity the poor lady who never gets a cocktail created in her honor. On Sunday at the Box, "Top Chef" host Padma Lakshmi actually got four.

headline: Oh, and It Helps to Have Talent, Too
summary: Have bustier, will travel, seems to be the message of the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame's 'Women Who Rock' exhibition, Jim Fusilli finds.

headline: Tertiary Education Booms In Iraqi Kurdistan
summary: Northern Iraq's Kurdish region has now become an oasis for education. Over the past five years, about 15 new universities have opened in the area.

headline: Pollution Rule Delayed Amid Cost Complaints
summary: The Obama administration suspended a new regulation aimed at cutting pollution from boilers at oil refineries, chemical plants and other factories, amid complaints by a range of industries over the potential cost.

headline: Troops in Mideast Face Breathing Ills
summary: U.S. veterans who served in Iraq and Afghanistan have a higher rate of debilitating respiratory illness than those deployed elsewhere.

headline: Medicare Revamp Exposes GOP Divide
summary: Gingrich's dismissal of the House Republican plan to overhaul Medicare provoked a rebuttal from the proposal's author, Rep. Ryan, highlighting a split over how hard to push a priority for the House GOP majority.

headline: Mexico Drug Gang Blamed for Massacre
summary: Guatemalan officials said Monday that Mexico's most brutal drug cartel was responsible for the massacre of at least 27 people, who were decapitated, the country's worst mass killing in years.

headline: New Thai Candidacy
summary: Allies of ousted Thai leader Thaksin nominated his sister as candidate for premier.

headline: A Liftoff as Giffords Looks On
summary: Space shuttle Endeavour blasted off for the final time Monday as Rep. Gabrielle Giffords—whose husband, Mark Kelly, is commanding the mission—looked on from the roof of the launch-control center, her staff said.

headline: Canadian Firms Defend TMX Counterbid
summary: A consortium of nine of Canada's largest banks and pension funds defended their $3.72 billion bid for the operator of the country's flagship stock exchange amid concerns their plan could meet objections from competition regulators.

headline: Profile: The New Breed of Green Techies
summary: There's a new breed of technology entrepreneurs in India. Deals India takes a close look at three such green-technology ventures in various stages of their development cycle.

headline: Enforcer Tapped for New York Agency
summary: New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo nominated his chief of staff and longtime ally, Benjamin M. Lawsky, to lead the state's new financial-services agency.

headline: At Cape Canaveral, the Rocket's Red Glare
summary: Watching Endeavour's last launch with my two daughters, I realized that when it comes to exploring space I want America to be in the driver's seat.

headline: Calls for FDA to Regulate Hair Straighteners
summary: Members of Congress are asking the Food and Drug Administration to issue a voluntary recall of two hair-straightening treatments sold in salons under the brand name Brazilian Blowout.

headline: Pills Offer Easier Way to Treat MS
summary: A number of new multiple-sclerosis medications that are beginning to hit the market promise to make it easier for patients to control flare-ups of the disease and slow its progression.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.
